definition: Liu Bang (256 or 247-195 BC), bandit leader who became first Han emperor Han Gaozu 漢高祖|汉高祖 (reigned 202-195 BC)
(classical) a type of battle-ax/to kill/to slaughter
surname Liu
country/nation/state

sentences.english: After my wound is healed, I will go to Liu Bang .
sentences.chinese: 等我的伤口治好了，我将会去刘邦那。

sentences.english: This night, they ran along with the path in ZeZhong.
sentences.chinese: 当晚，刘邦一行人在泽中小道逃跑。

sentences.english: Liu Bang established Western Han Dynasty, and he consolidated the centralized feudal state.
sentences.chinese: 刘邦建立了西汉，巩固了中央集权的封建国家。

sentences.english: Liu Bang established the powerful Han Dynasty in 206 B. C.
sentences.chinese: 公元前206年，刘邦建立了强大的汉王朝。

sentences.english: Third, Liu Bang are not satisfied with the feudality from Shiang Yu.
sentences.chinese: 三是刘邦对项羽分封的不满。

sentences.english: How did Liu Bang, who was described by Tai Shigong , embody the life wisdom of the ancients?
sentences.chinese: 太史公笔下的刘邦，又是如何表现古人的人生聪明？

sentences.english: Liu bang from _ the uprising to WangMang reigned han dynasty, across two hundred DuoNian of time and space.
sentences.chinese: 从_刘邦起义反秦到王莽篡汉，横跨二百多年时空。

sentences.english: Liu Bang also could enjoy pop music in palace chambers.
sentences.chinese: 连刘邦也只能在宫闱中享受一番家乡情调。

definition: Xiang Yu the Conqueror (232-202 BC), warlord defeated by first Han emperor
Xiao He (-193 BC), famous strategist and chancellor, fought on Liu Bang's 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] side during the Chu-Han Contention 楚漢戰爭|楚汉战争[Chu3 Han4 Zhan4 zheng1]
Han Xin (-196 BC), famous general of first Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1]

Cao Cao (155-220), famous statesman and general at the end of Han, noted poet and calligrapher, later warlord, founder and first king of Cao Wei 曹魏, father of Emperor Cao Pi 曹丕/the main villain of novel the Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义
Liu Bei (161-223), warlord at the end of the Han dynasty and founder of the Han kingdom of Shu 蜀漢|蜀汉 (c. 200-263), later the Shu Han dynasty
posthumous name of the first Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦 (256 or 247-195 BC), reigned 202-195 BC
Zhou Bo (?-169 BC), military man and politician at the Qin-Han transition, a founding minister of Western Han

Cao Can (-190 BC), second chancellor of Han Dynasty, contributed to its founding by fighting on Liu Bang's 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] side during the Chu-Han Contention 楚漢戰爭|楚汉战争[Chu3 Han4 Zhan4 zheng1]/also pr. [Cao2 Shen1]
Liu Chan 劉禪|刘禅 (207-271), son of Liu Bei, reigned as Shu Han emperor 233-263

Zhuge Liang (181-234), military leader and prime minister of Shu Han 蜀漢|蜀汉 during the Three Kingdoms period/the main hero of the fictional Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义, where he is portrayed as a sage and military genius/mastermind
Chu-Han Contention (206-202 BC), power struggle between Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] of Han and Xiang Yu 項羽|项羽[Xiang4 Yu3] of Chu
Lü Bu (-198), general and warlord
Emperor Wen of Han (202-157 BC), fourth Han emperor, personal name Liu Heng 劉恆|刘恒[Liu2 Heng2], reigned 180-157 BC
Sun Quan (reigned 222-252), southern warlord and king of state of Wu 吳|吴 in the Three Kingdoms period

Guan Yu (-219), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, fearsome fighter famous for virtue and loyalty/posthumously worshipped and identified with the guardian Bodhisattva Sangharama
Qin Ershi (229-207 BC), second Qin emperor
